origin: Old English brecan (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch breken and German brechen, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin frangere ‘to break’.

definitions.definition: Separate or cause to separate into pieces as a result of a blow, shock, or strain.
definitions.example: the rope broke with a loud snap
the new government broke the pattern of growth

definitions.definition: Fail to observe (a law, regulation, or agreement)
definitions.example: the district attorney says she will prosecute retailers who break the law

definitions.definition: Crush the emotional strength, spirit, or resistance of.
definitions.example: the idea was to better the prisoners, not to break them
the weather broke and thunder rumbled through a leaden sky

definitions.definition: (of news or a scandal) suddenly become public.
definitions.example: since the news broke I've received thousands of wonderful letters

definitions.definition: (chiefly of an attacking player or team, or of a military force) make a rush or dash in a particular direction.
definitions.example: the flight broke to the right and formed a defensive circle

definitions.definition: An interruption of continuity or uniformity.
definitions.example: the magazine has been published without a break since 1950

definitions.definition: A pause in work or during an activity or event.
definitions.example: I need a break from mental activity
he stopped to wait for a break in the traffic

definitions.definition: An instance of breaking something, or the point where something is broken.
definitions.example: a break in the valve was being repaired

definitions.definition: A rush or dash in a particular direction, especially by an attacking player or team.
definitions.example: he made a bounce pass for a basket on the break in the second quarter

definitions.definition: An opportunity or chance, especially one leading to professional success.
A consecutive series of successful shots, scoring a specified number of points.
definitions.example: a break of 83 put him in front for the first time
